Context:
The text provides information about a ventilation, air conditioning and refrigeration (HVAC/R) advanced diploma program offered at George Brown College. In the first two years of the program, students study residential and some light commercial systems. In the third year, there is an additional focus on commercial systems. The curriculum covers air system and hydronic (water) theory, design distribution systems, selecting appropriate fans, pumps, heating and cooling plants, and system controls for larger buildings. The program follows industry-standard design practices for environmentally responsible and energy-efficient residential, commercial, and industrial systems, as established by the Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Institute (HRAI), the American Society of Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE), and the Canada Green Building Council.

Upon completion of the program, students have sufficient training to challenge the Gas Fitter 2 provincial qualification exam and obtain the Gas Fitter 2 certification. In the third semester, they are assisted in preparing to challenge the Ontario Ministry of Consumer Affairs and Housing HVAC House exam to obtain a Building Code Identification Number (BCIN). The text notes that there are further requirements to qualify for the BCIN beyond passing the HVAC House exam. Successful graduates may find employment opportunities in consulting engineering and architectural firms, design/build contractors, school boards, commercial refrigeration installation and maintenance companies, building automation and control companies, building maintenance, HVAC/R manufacturing, sales, and distribution companies, as well as management careers or self-employment.

Context: The text provides information about the required courses for a HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning) program offered by the college. Each course has a unique code and name. The courses are distributed across six semesters. Some of the courses cover refrigeration theory, electrical fundamentals, gas technician training, math, communication skills, building science, entrepreneurship, and various HVAC design and estimation topics. Additionally, AutoCAD and AutoCAD for HVAC courses are offered in Semester 5 and 6, respectively. The students might be required to take a general education elective in some semesters as well.

Context:
Program: Law and Construction Contracts

Communication Course Requirement:
- Students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) before progressing to COMM 2000.
- This course does not count towards graduation requirements.
- More information can be found at Assessment Centre.

General Education Electives:
- Detailed course outlines are available.
- Program Learning Outcomes:
  - Relate effectively to supervisors, coworkers and customers in heating, ventilation, air conditioning and refrigeration industry.
  - Comply with applicable acts, regulations, legislation and codes for personal and public safety.
  - Solve scientific, mathematical and engineering problems related to energy system design, operation and installation for commercial and industrial complexes.
  - Prepare and analyze detailed drawings and compile technical specifications for energy systems.
  - Design, operate and install energy systems for commercial and industrial complexes.
  - Develop strategies for ongoing personal and professional development.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition (Fall 2022): $3,906.00 *
- International Tuition (Fall 2023): $17,531.00 **
- Additional costs are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and later.
- More information for international students can be found on the International Fees and Related Costs page.

Financial Assistance:
- This program is approved for OSAP (Ontario Student Assistance Program) funding.

Admission Requirements:
- Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent.
- Required courses include grade 12 English (C or U) and either grade 11 math (M or U) or grade 12 math (C or U).
- Mature students can apply if they are 19 years of age.

* Amounts listed are for the first two semesters.
** Amounts listed are for programs starting in Fall 2023.

Disclaimer: The information contained in this website is subject to change without notice. It should not be viewed as a representation, offer or warranty. Students are responsible for verifying George Brown College fee requirements.

* Applicants who are or have a grade 12 (C or U) and are 19 years of age or older without an OSSD can apply as mature students.
* Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math, or consider upgrading to achieve the necessary credits.
* College or university credits may qualify applicants for course exemptions. More information can be found on the Transfer Guide.
* International students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements and apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
* Contact the School of Apprenticeship and Skilled Trades at 416-415-5000, ext. 6711 or email skilledtrades@georgebrown.ca for more information about the college.
* International students can also contact one of the international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry on the International Contact Us page.
* Campus tours and information sessions can be booked through the college's website.
* Program-related options include Heating, Refrigeration, and Air Conditioning Technician (T160), Electrical Techniques (T167), and Plumbing Techniques (T165).
* Applicants can sign up to receive tailored resources to help with their application process.
* The application form requires the applicant's first name and last name.
